Subject: Submission of proposals for Direct Recruitments to Union Public Service
Commission (UPSC) on annual basis - reg.

The undersigned is directed to refer to the subject cited above and to draw the attention
of all Administrative Secretaries, UT of Ladakh to the letter dated 25th November, 2024 of the
Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) (copy enclosed). It is stated that the UPSC will
accept requisitions for direct recruitment, complete in all aspects, in the UPSC-33 proforma
from 01st January, 2026 to 31st March, 2026; through slots available on the Single Window
System. The bookings for prior appointment of slots will be made available on the online web
portal of UPSC from 15.12.2025 onwards.

2. The UPSC-33 proforma checklist, inter alia, provides that reservation for SCs, STs,
and other reserved categories have to be worked out as per the reservation roster laid down in
the DoP&T OM No. 36012/2/96-Estt. (Res) dated 02.07.1997.

This has been examined in the General Administration Department (GAD), and given
that reservation in the UT of Ladakh is governed by statute, namely the J&K Reservation Act,
2004 (as amended by the Ministry of Law & Justice, Government of India vide the Union
Territory of Ladakh Reservation (Amendment) Regulation, 2025 (No. 1 of 2025) dated 02nd
June 2025), in its application to the UT of Ladakh, read with the J&K Reservation Rules, 2005
(as amended by the Social & Tribal Welfare Department, UT of Ladakh, vide S.O. 77 dated
27.06.2025); reservations to the posts in the Administration of UT to Ladakh have to be
governed strictly in accordance with the provisions of the aforementioned Act, Rules, and
Regulations.

3. Therefore, the Departments are required to work out reservations for various reserved
categories in accordance with the roster preparation procedure as laid down under the J&K
Reservation Rules, 2005 read with S.O. 77 dated 27.06.2025, notified by the Social & Tribal
Welfare Department, UT of Ladakh.

4. A copy of the requisition for the Medical Officer vacancies, submitted by the Health &
Medical Education Department, UT of Ladakh, to the UPSC during the calendar year 2025,
completed in all respects along with the formats of certificates, is enclosed for the reference of

Subject: Requisition of Direct Recruitment of 125 Medical Officer posts of Health and
Medical Education Department of the Administration of UT of Ladakh to UPSC.
Respected Sir,
The undersigned is directed and authorized to submit a requisition for the direct recruitment of
125 Medical Officer (Level-9, Rs. 52700-166700) in the Health and Medical Education Department,
Administration of Union territory of Ladakh, to the Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) for
recruitment.

2. The requisition is submitted in the prescribed proforma (UPSC-33) in duplicate, along with all
necessary enclosures, including the notified Recruitment Rules vide S.O. 58 dated 26.05.2025
(Appendix A) and UPSC Advice Note No. 10624 dated 16.05.2025 (Appendix B).

3. The recruitment is governed by the following specific regulations and requirements, as
applicable to the Union territory of Ladakh, which are not covered under standard UPSC guidelines,
namely:
1. Applicability of Reservation Law:
The recruitment adheres to the Jammu and
Kashmir Reservation Act, 2004 (Appendix C) as extended to the Union Territory of Ladakh
and amended by the Union Territory of Ladakh Reservation (Amendment) Regulation, 2025
(No. 1 of 2025) (Appendix D), notified by the Ministry of Law and Justice, Government of
India, and the Union Territory of Ladakh Reservation (Amendment) Rules, 2025, notified vide
S.O. 77 dated 27.06.2025 (Appendix E) by the Social & Tribal Welfare Department, UT of
Ladakh.
2. Domicile Requirement:
Candidates must hold a valid Domicile Certificate
issued under Rule 4 of the Ladakh Civil Services Decentralization and Recruitment - Grant of
Domicile Certificate (Procedure) Rules, 2025 (Appendix F) notified by the Ministry of Home
Affairs, Government of India and published in the Gazette of India (Extraordinary) dated
03.06.2025.
Domicile Certificates shall be issued by the Competent Authority (i.e. Tehsildar) in the
Administration of UT of Ladakh, which shall be issued to the following Category(s):
(a) Category A: Holding Ladakh Resident Certificate (L. R. C.) or eligible to be issued
L.R.C.
(b) Category B: Children of L.R.C. holders or those eligible for holding L.R.C.

**Page 4**

3. Reservation Structure (under Rule 4 of the Union territory of Ladakh Reservation
(Amendment) Rules, 2025):
(a) Vertical Reservation:
(i) Scheduled Tribes (ST): 80% as notified by the Constitution (Jammu and
Kashmir) Scheduled Tribes Order, 1989 as (amended by the Constitution (Jammu and
Kashmir) Scheduled Tribes Order (Amendment) Act, 2024 (No. 3 of 2024)) (Appendix
K)
(i) Residents of Areas Adjoining Actual Line of Control (ALC): 04 %, which is
notified by the Administration of UT of Ladakh vide S.O. 75 dated 27.06.2025
(Appendix G)
(ii) Scheduled Castes (SC): 01 %
(iii) Economically Weaker Sections (EWS): 10 %
(iv) Open Merit (Unreserved): 05 %
(b) Horizontal Reservation:
(i) Persons with Benchmark Disabilities (PwBD): 04% (for posts identified
under Section 34 of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016).
It must be noted that reservation under Scheduled Tribe (ST), Scheduled Caste (SC)
and Residents of Areas Adjoining Actual Line of Control (ALC) categories is admissible only
to the holders of Domicile Certificate issued on the basis of L.R.C.

4. Single Reservation Claim (as per provisions of Section 19 of the J&K Reservation
Act, 2004): A candidate belonging to more than one category shall be entitled to claim the
benefit of reservation in one category only, as per his choice.
Accordingly, candidates who fall under more than one reserved category (e.g. ST and
ALC, or EWS & ALC or SC & EWS) must exercise their choice of category at the time of
application. This choice shall be final and cannot be modified or withdrawn at any later stage
of the recruitment process.

5. Mandatory Submission of Certificates:
Candidates claiming reservation
must submit valid, original certificates in the prescribed formats for UPSC scrutiny, issued by
the competent authority.
The formats are as follows:
(ii) Scheduled Caste / Scheduled Tribe Certificate: Annexure - I (issued by Tehsildar).
(iii) Certificate of Being a Resident of an Area Adjoining the Actual Line of Control
(ALC): Annexure - II (issued by Tehsildar).
(iv) Domicile Certificate: Annexure - III (issued by the Tehsildar under Rule 5(1) of the
Ladakh Civil Services Decentralization and Recruitment Grant of Domicile Certificate
(Procedure) Rules, 2025).
(v) Economically Weaker Sections (EWS) Certificate: Annexure - IV (issued by District
Magistrate / Additional District Magistrate / Sub-Divisional Magistrate / Tehsildar).
(vi) Persons with Benchmark Disabilities (PwBD) Certificate: Annexure-V (Application
Format for obtaining PwBD certificate), VI, VII, VIII (certificates issued by Members /
Chairperson of Medical Board, countersigned by Medical Superintendent / CMO / Head of
Hospital).

**Page 5**

4. (vii) Government Employees Certificate (for age relaxation): Annexure-IX (issued by
Head of Department).
(viii) Declaration by Employed Applicants: Annexure-X (self-declaration by the
applicant).
6. Preparation of Select List (as per Rule 7 of the Union Territory of Ladakh Reservation
(Amendment) Rules, 2025):
a. A consolidated merit list of all eligible candidates, irrespective of category,
will be prepared, followed by a second list for unreserved vacancies and a third list for
reserved category vacancies (starting with EWS).
b. Unfilled EWS vacancies will be treated as unreserved and filled in the same
select list.
c. Reserved category vacancies (except EWS) with insufficient candidates will
be treated as backlog under Section 5 of the Jammu and Kashmir Reservation Act, 2004.
d. Horizontal reservation for PwBD will be applied as specified.
e. The final select list will be based on merit, ensuring inter se seniority.
The vacancies (125 permanent posts) have arisen due to the apportionment of posts from the
erstwhile State of Jammu & Kashmir to the Union Territory of Ladakh, with 100% of the 191 sanctioned
Medical Officer posts designated for direct recruitment.
The reservation roster complies with the DoP&T OM No. 36039/1/2019-Estt (Res) dated
31.01.2019 and DoP&T OM No. 36035/02/2017-Estt (Res) dated 15.01.2018 for PwBD.
The posts are identified as suitable for PwBD categories, with 05 vacancies reserved for the
Person with Benchmark Disabilities (PwBDs).
5. The recruitment is being made specific for the Union Territory of Ladakh, as per the provisions
contained in the J&K Civil Service Decentralization and Recruitment Act, 2010 (Appendix H) as
amended by the Ladakh Civil Services Decentralization and Recruitment (Amendment) Regulation,
2025 (No. 4 of 2025) (Appendix I) issued by the Ministry of Law& Justice, Govt. of India and J&K
Reservation Act, 2004 (as amended by the Ladakh Reservation(Amendment) Regulation, 2025 (No.1
of 2025) issued by the Ministry of Law& Justice, Govt. of India.
Further, the recruitment is to be made for individuals / candidates who are domiciles of the UT
of Ladakh, as per the Ladakh Civil Services Decentralization and Recruitment-Grant of Domicile
Certificate (Procedure) Rules, 2025 notified by Ministry of Home Affairs, Govt. of India in Gazette of
India (Extraordinary) dated 03/06/2025.
The recruitment for the reserved categories is also being made uniquely and exclusively for the
residents of Ladakh as per Rule 4 of the Ladakh Reservation (Amendment) Regulation, 2025 notified
vide S.O. 77 dated 27/06/2025.
Therefore, the requirement of NOC from DoPT (Surplus Cell) and DGR, M/o Defence is not
required; and the certification to this effect is included in the UPSC-33 proforma.
6. To compensate for the loss of more than five and half years since the establishment of the Union
territory of Ladakh, where no Gazetted recruitments could take place; the Administration has granted
one-time special relaxation in the upper age limit prescribed in column 6 of the RRs, by five (05) years
for the recruitment to be conducted during the year 2025 and 2026; vide Order No. 280 – LA (GAD) of
2025 dated 30.06.2025 (Appendix J).
By the same order the reserved category of ALC has been accorded with a age relaxation of
five (05) years.

**Page 6**

Administration of Union territory of Ladakh is the requisitioning authority for referral of these
vacancies in terms of rule 2(1) of the Jammu and Kashmir Civil Services Decentralization Rules, 2010
(Appendix L).

title: Mizoram Governor Attends Northeast Conclave at GeoSmart Conference & Expo 2025
content:
**Reference:** 288/2025-2026

**Aizawl, the 2nd December, 2025:**Mizoram Governor General (Dr) Vijay Kumar Singh, PVSM, AVSM, YSM (Retd) attended the the North East Conclave held in New Delhi under the GeoSmart World Conference & Expo 2025 on tuesday.

In his address, Mizoram Governor General (Dr) Vijay Kumar Singh called for geospatial intelligence, unified platforms and climate-ready systems to drive sustainable development across the region. He reflected on how the Northeast had long remained a distant and less explored region, often forgotten because of its challenging terrain and limited connectivity. He highlighted that the last 11-12 years have marked a dramatic shift, with unprecedented efforts to bridge infrastructural gaps and integrate the region more closely with India's development trajectory. Illustrating the magnitude of progress, he shared the story of Mizoram's railway connectivity, a project launched in 2015 that has successfully brought the railway line to Aizawl which demonstrates the complexity of terrain and the determination driving transformative change. "This kind of engineering achievement was unheard of earlier, and it reflects the commitment to ensure our Northeast never remains what it used to be," he said.

General (Dr) Vijay Kumar Singh emphasised Mizoram's unique position in India's national fabric-a region of extraordinary biodiversity, cultural richness, and strategic importance, yet shaped by fragile slopes, seismic vulnerability, and dispersed settlements. These very challenges, he said, underline why advanced geospatial and digital technologies must be embedded into every stage of planning.

He called geospatial intelligence a force multiplier for development, explaining how terrain-informed governance, remote sensing, digital twins and GIS-based modelling can guide everything from road alignments and service delivery to environmental protection and disaster preparedness. For a state like Mizoram, where linear settlements stretch along narrow hill ridges and ecological sensitivity is high, such tools are essential for safeguarding both livelihoods and landscapes.

He noted that the Northeast's climatic realities, frequent landslides, cloudbursts, long monsoon spells and high seismicity make predictive technology indispensable. With modern remote sensing satellites, Doppler radars, hydrological models and loT sensors, the region can forecast landslides up to 72 hours in advance, monitor river levels in real time, and issue early warnings that reach both citizens and security forces. "Technology is no longer a luxury for the Northeast. It is the foundation of a climate-resilient future," he said.

He spotlighted the strategic significance of Mizoram's international borders with Bangladesh and Myanmar. He stressed that smart connectivity and secure border management-using drones, sensors, integrated surveillance and resilient communication systems are critical for combating illegal movements, enhancing disaster response, and supporting security personnel deployed in difficult terrain.

Highlighting Mizoram's vast potential in agroforestry, bamboo processing, renewable energy, ecotourism, horticulture, and traditional crafts, he underscored how technology can catalyse sustainable economic growth. Precision agriculture, soil health mapping, yield prediction, and spatial planning, he said, can help reduce dependence on shifting cultivation and strengthen long-term ecological balance.

He concluded by outlining future pathways for the region, emphasising the need for a unified geospatial platform for the entire Northeast, a strong indigenous drone ecosystem, and large-scale skill development in GIS, remote sensing, Al-based terrain analytics, UAV operations, and climate modelling. He called for deeper civil-military collaboration, greater involvement of academia and startups, and motivation for youth to embrace technology-oriented careers. With characteristic warmth, he added that professionals from across India should spend time working in the Northeast "a place where the air is clean, the skies are blue, and the possibilities are endless." He ended with a powerful message, "Mizoram and the Northeast are not just regions of hills and valleys, they are lands of immense possibility. With wisdom, sensitivity and technological vision, we can build a future that is resilient, sustainable, secure and prosperous for generations to come."

The North East Conclave at GeoSmart World Conference & Expo 2025 brought the spotlight firmly on the wider North-Eastern region, underscoring how.technology-led development is reshaping one of India's most biodiverse and strategically significant geographies.

Hmarchhak chu a chheng chhiat avang leh inkalpawhna that loh avanga hun rei tak chhung ngaihven loh leh daidar loh a nih dan tarlangin, tunhnai kum 11-12 chhungin a hmelhmang thlak hlawk thei danglamna thlen a ni a, tunhma zawnga thleng ngai lo hmasawnna ruhrel lian tham tak takte siam niin India hmun dangte hmasawnna nen thlunzawm tlat a ni, a ti a. Tunhnaia India railway network-a Aizawl thlunzawm a ni chu mellung pawimawh tak a nih thu leh tlangram chhengchhe taka hmasawnna thlen tura hmalakna chu fakawm tiin, "Hetiang enginnering hlawhtlinna hi tunhma zawnga la hriat ngai loh niin, hei hian India sawrkarin hmarchhak chu a awmdan ngaia awm mai lova tihhmasawn a tum zia a lantir a ni, a ti bawk.

Mizoram Larsap chuan India ram ruhrela Mizoram pawimawh bikna sawiin, Mizoram chu biodiversity hausa bik, hnam ziarang hausa leh hmun pawimawh taka awm a nih thu a sawi a. Hmun awih leh rualrem lo, lirnghing thlen duhna leh tlang hrang hranga tlem te tea inbawk hran thliah a nih thu sawiin, hengte avang hian ruahmanna siam reng rengah geospatial leh digital technology changkang ber berte mamawh a nih thu a sawi a. Geospatial intelligence chu thil thlen dan tur lo hriat lawkna, kawng siamna, environment humhalhna, chhiatrupna thleng thei leh pawimawh dang dangahte a hman tangkai theih thu a sawi a. Hmarchhakah khuarel thil thlen dan tur engemawchen hrilh lawk thei technology tel lova khawsak a harsat thu sawiin, "Technology hi khawsak tinuamtu ni tawh lovin, sik leh sa inthlak thin laka insiamrem zung zung thei tura hmanraw pawimawh a ni," a ti a. Myanmar leh Bangladesh nena inrina ramri pawimawhna sawiin, drone, sensor, integrated surveillance leh inbiakpawhna tha tak nena dan lova chetvelna ven a tul thu a sawi bawk.

Agroforestry, mau sawngbawlna, renewable energy, ecotourism, horticulture leh kutthemthiamna lama Mizoram theihna tarlangin, technology hmanga hmasawn thlen belh theih a nih thu a sawi a. Awmze neia loneih, lei that leh that loh enfiah, thar theih zat tur zirna leh tangkai taka ram hmante chu kum tin loneih sawn thin leh kan vela thil awmte rualkhai taka awm tlan theihna atana pawimawh a nih thu a sawi a. Northeast pumpui tana geospatial platform inang tlang hman a tul thu sawiin, ram chhung siam ngei drone hman te, GIS, khaw awmdan hrilhlawkna, Al hmanga hmunhma zirchianna, UAV leh climate modelling chhawr tangkai tura thiamna inzirtir nasat a tul thu a sawi a. Hmasawnna thlen turin thawhhona tha neih a tul thu a sawi bawk.

GeoSmart World Conference & Expo 2025 hnuaia North East Conclave hian India hmarchhak pumpui chu mitfuknaah siamin, technology hmanga hmasawnnain India rama biodiversity hausa leh hmun pawimawh tak chang mek hmarchhak state-a danglamna a thlen dante chu thlurbing a ni.

The Union Territory of Lakshadweep, a chain of ecologically sensitive and
geographically isolated islands, faces unique challenges in connectivity,
emergency response, and sustainable development. Kadmat Island, known
for its natural beauty and vibrant community life, relies primarily on sea
transport, with helicopter services playing a vital role in meeting urgent needs
such as medical evacuations, administrative travel, and delivery of essential
supplies. Given the operational limitations of the existing helipad, including
space constraints, safety concerns, and proximity to residential areas, there is
a critical need to relocate and upgrade the facility to meet evolving aviation
safety standards and growing community requirements.

In response to these needs, the Administration of Lakshadweep has proposed
the acquisition of approximately 7,000 square metres of land for the shifting
and development of the helipad at Kadmat Island. The project aims to
enhance operational safety, improve emergency evacuation capability,
support controlled tourism growth, and strengthen the island's connectivity
with other islands and the mainland.

This Social Impact Assessment (SIA) Report has been prepared in accordance
with the provisions of the Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land
Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act, 2013 (RFCTLARR Act) and
corresponding Lakshadweep regulations. It assesses the potential social
impacts of the proposed land acquisition, documents stakeholder concerns
and expectations, and recommends mitigation measures to ensure that the
project is implemented in an equitable, inclusive, and environmentally
responsible manner.

The findings of this report are based on a thorough review of land records, field
surveys, community consultations, and inputs from relevant institutions and
departments. It is intended to serve as a foundation for transparent decision-
making and participatory planning, ensuring that the proposed helipad at
Kadmat Island becomes a model for sustainable infrastructure development,
improved accessibility, and enhanced quality of life in India's island territories.

1. Back ground of the Project and its details

The Union Territory of Lakshadweep comprises 36 small coral islands in the
Arabian Sea with a total land area of just 32.62 sq. km, of which only 10
islands are inhabited. As per the 2011 Census, the total population is 64,473.
The islands are ecologically sensitive and geographically isolated, relying
on air and sea connectivity primarily via Cochin. The administration seeks to
balance infrastructure development with ecological conservation to
enhance residents' quality of life and support sustainable tourism across the
territory.

Kadmat Island, part of the Union Territory of Lakshadweep, is a narrow coral
island located approximately 407 kilometres west of Kochi in the Arabian
Sea. It has a total land area of about 3.2 square kilometres, stretching
roughly 9 kilometres in length with an average width of 550 metres. The
island is surrounded by a large lagoon on its western side, covering an area
of nearly 25 square kilometres, which supports rich marine biodiversity and
traditional fishing activities. As per the 2011 Census, Kadmat has a
population of around 5,400 residents, predominantly engaged in fishing,
coconut cultivation, and small-scale service activities. The island is known
for its scenic beaches, vibrant coral reefs, and limited but essential
infrastructure catering to local needs and controlled tourism.

The proposed project for the shifting and development of the helipad at
Kadmat Island is aimed at improving air connectivity, enhancing
emergency response capabilities, and supporting the socio-economic
development of the island. The existing helipad location faces operational
constraints and limitations in expansion, necessitating relocation to a more
suitable site. The new site has been identified after considering safety,
accessibility, and minimal environmental disturbance. For this purpose, a
total of 7,000 square metres of land is proposed to be acquired. The
selected land parcel ensures adequate space for the construction of the
helipad, associated infrastructure, and safety buffer zones in compliance
with aviation norms. The improved facility is expected to facilitate regular
helicopter services, ensure timely medical evacuations, improve disaster
preparedness, and promote sustainable tourism, thereby directly benefiting
the local population and overall development of Kadmat Island.

The Social Impact Assessment (SIA) confirms that while the project is widely
recognized as essential for public welfare, community consultations
emphasized the importance of minimizing disruption to common use areas
and ensuring cultural and ecological sensitivity. To mitigate any potential

Demographic and Educational Profile:

The affected families belong entirely to the Scheduled Tribe (ST) category
and follow Islam as their religion. In total, 18 families comprising 140

education. All children (ages 6-14) were reported to be enrolled in school,

higher education are limited locally, requiring migration to the mainland,
particularly to Kerala. The total population affected by the proposed
project is 140 individuals, comprising 28 children below 18 years of age, 88 adults
between 18 and 55 years, and 24 elderly persons above 55 years. Out of the
total, 98 individuals are reported to be married.

Livelihoods, Occupation and Income Sources:

The affected households in the proposed land acquisition area maintain a
mixed livelihood pattern, combining agriculture, coconut farming, and
service-based employment. Among the adult population above 18 years,
the primary occupations include 40 homemakers, 31 self-employed
individuals, 17 government employees, 16 unemployed persons, 6 retired
employees, 1 retired driver, and only 1 coconut farmer. Out of the six
landowning families, three fall under the Below Poverty Line (BPL) category,
indicating economic vulnerability. While some households possess small
parcels of alternative agricultural land, these are insufficient to ensure full
livelihood continuity. Income information was largely undisclosed; only one
household reported a monthly income of ₹10,000, which is modest and
unstable. Overall, the economic base of the affected households is fragile,
combining low-return land-based activities with limited and uncertain
service employment opportunities.

Basic amenities are present, including pucca houses with toilet facilities,
cooking fuel through LPG and/or firewood, and access to drinking water
from either private wells or desalination plant supply. This semi-subsistence
lifestyle reflects a low-income and insecure rural household economy,
combining traditional land-based practices with limited formal
employment opportunities, making these households more vulnerable to
livelihood disruption due to land acquisition.

7. Impact on Physical Resources

Land, Soil, and Vegetation:

The acquisition of 7,000 square metres of land for the helipad will result in
the conversion of a portion of sandy coastal soil, which is generally
unsuitable for conventional agriculture but well-suited for coconut
plantation. The identified site currently supports about 54 coconut trees,
which represent a valuable livelihood resource for the affected households.
While the soil itself is not highly productive for food crops, the removal of
these coconut trees will directly impact an important component of the
island's subsistence and cash economy.

Water conditions in the project area are also influenced by its coastal
location. The soil and groundwater at the site are saline due to proximity to
the sea, unlike the central inland parts of Kadmat Island where dug wells
provide relatively salinity-free freshwater. At present, all households on the
island have access to desalinated water supplied once or twice a week,
which supplements limited groundwater resources.

Overall, while the direct impact on soil productivity is minimal, the loss of
coconut trees and saline-sensitive land characteristics require attention.
Mitigation measures such as compensatory coconut plantation in
alternative locations should be considered to balance ecological and
livelihood concerns.

Impact on Common Property Resources and Natural Systems:

The proposed helipad site does not overlap with any common property
resources such as community wells, grazing land, or public buildings,
ensuring no disruption to shared community assets. Natural systems,
including the island's lagoon ecosystem and marine resources, will remain
unaffected as the location is away from sensitive coastal and aquatic
zones. With appropriate construction safeguards, the project will maintain
the integrity of local natural systems while enhancing overall connectivity
for the community.

1. Background of the Project and its details
Social Impact Assessment

The Union Territory of Lakshadweep comprises 36 small coral islands in
the Arabian Sea with a total land area of just 32.62 sq. km, of which only
10 islands are inhabited. As per the 2011 Census, the total population is
64,473. The islands are ecologically sensitive and geographically
isolated, relying on air and sea connectivity primarily via Cochin. The
administration seeks to balance infrastructure development with
ecological conservation to enhance residents' quality of life and support
sustainable tourism across the territory.

Kadmat Island, spanning 3.84 sq. km with a population of 7,566 (2011
Census), is a key island in Lakshadweep due to its only aerodrome that
links the UT to mainland India-situated at 11.2241° N latitude and
72.7762°E longitude. Known for its coral-rich lagoons and pristine
beaches, Kadmat holds significant ecological and tourism potential.
However, the western side of the island suffers from inadequate
infrastructure, limiting access, development opportunities, and disaster
preparedness. The island is now poised for strategic interventions to
enhance its connectivity and eco-tourism offerings. However, the school
currently lacks a dedicated and structured outdoor space where
students and others can engage in physical activities, sports, and
recreational learning in a safe and organised environment. Recognising
this critical need, the Administration has proposed the development of
a playground within the Government Senior Basic School campus at
Kadmat Island to support the physical, mental, and social development
of children.

The proposed Government Senior Basic School Playground at Kadmat
Island is envisioned as a safe, inclusive, and student-friendly open space
that supports physical education, sports, and recreational activities for
school children. A total 9 number of households were affected, and the
project involves the acquisition of approximately 1,570 square metres of
land exclusively for the construction of the playground within the
Government Senior Basic School campus. The planned development is
expected to include basic sports infrastructure, play equipment, shaded
seating areas, boundary fencing, and landscaping elements suited to
the local environment. Special attention is being given to ensuring
safety, accessibility for all children, including girls and those with
disabilities and integration with the existing school layout. The design will
reflect ecological sensitivity by incorporating native vegetation, natural
drainage, and open space planning that enhances the learning

long-standing need for a safe, structured, and inclusive outdoor space

limiting opportunities for sports, recreational learning, and physical
education-an essential component of holistic child development
under the national education framework.

this critical gap by developing a student-friendly, ecologically sensitive,
and well-demarcated play space within the school premises. The
proposed site spans approximately 1,570 square metres, identified as the

such as open play fields, basic sports infrastructure, shaded seating, and
safety features. The land proposed for acquisition comprises specific
private land parcels adjoining the school, carefully chosen to ensure

Poverty, Vulnerability, and Access to Welfare Schemes:

All the affected families fall under the Above Poverty Line (APL)

vulnerability are evident as 17 women and nine men are unemployed,

as PDS, pensions, and scholarships to sustain their livelihoods.

Assets, Housing, and Infrastructure Access:

The acquisition land for the proposed playground in Kadmat contains
no residential households or housing structures. Still, it has coconut trees
as the only productive assets. In contrast, the wider community has
access to basic infrastructure such as electricity, PDS, schools, and
health facilities, though water supply and external connectivity remain
limited.

Social Structure, Community Dynamics, and Aspirations:

The community in Kadmat is characterised by a close-knit social
structure rooted in kinship and shared livelihoods such as coconut
farming and fishing, where collective decision-making and Gram Sabha
participation are strong, and aspirations are centred on better
educational opportunities, recreational spaces like the proposed
playground, improved livelihood options, and enhanced connectivity
with the mainland.

Social Impact Assessment
1. Background of the Project and its details
The Union Territory of Lakshadweep comprises 36 small coral islands in the
Arabian Sea, with a total land area of just 32.62 square kilometres, of which
only 10 islands are inhabited. As per the 2011 Census, the total population
is 64,473. The islands are ecologically fragile and geographically isolated,
depending heavily on air and sea connectivity via Kochi for most
economic, medical, and logistical functions. The Administration of
Lakshadweep has been actively working towards balancing infrastructure
development with ecological conservation aiming to improve the quality
of life for its residents while promoting sustainable, culturally grounded
tourism across the territory.
Agatti Island, with a geographical area of 3.22 square kilometres and a
population of 7,566 (Census 2011), is one of the most strategically significant
islands in the archipelago. Situated at 10°51′ North latitude and 72°11′ East
longitude, and located approximately 459 kilometres west of Kochi, Agatti
serves as the primary gateway to Lakshadweep, being home to the
territory's only operational airport. Its picturesque white sand beaches,
vibrant coral ecosystems, and lagoon-rich geography give it immense
ecological and tourism potential. However, the island currently lacks a
structured, multifunctional public space where residents and visitors can
meaningfully interact, engage in economic activities, and access cultural,
recreational, and community services in an organised setting. Recognising
this gap, the Administration has proposed the development of a well-
planned City Centre at Agatti Island as a flagship initiative under Kavaratti
Smart City Limited.
The proposed City Centre is envisioned as a vibrant public precinct that
integrates civic amenities, recreational spaces, and tourism-oriented
services in a manner compatible with the island's ecological sensitivity and
socio-cultural fabric. The project involves approximately 12,241 square
metres of land, which includes 1931 sq.mtr privately owned plots, which is
to be acquired, and remaining government/institutional parcels. Key
components of the City Centre include a food kiosk, souvenir and
handicraft shops, sky café, wellness spa, children's play areas, maze
garden, performance pavilion, water features, viewing decks, smart
sanitation blocks, locker and changing facilities, seating zones, and secure
parking areas. Special attention is being given to architectural design,
landscape aesthetics, and accessibility features, ensuring that the space
serves both local residents and tourists. Provisions for digital displays, public
information services, and sustainable features such as rainwater harvesting
and native vegetation planting have also been incorporated into the plan.
Prepared by APARC PVT. LTD.
Page 1
Development of City Centre
Community consultations conducted as part of the Social Impact
Assessment (SIA) process revealed broad-based interest among Agatti
residents in the potential benefits of the City Centre project particularly in
terms of improving local infrastructure, expanding livelihood opportunities,
and creating a dignified, inclusive public space. At the same time,
participants highlighted the need to protect the island's ecological integrity
and to avoid disruption to existing services, informal economic activities,
and commonly used public spaces. These findings have informed the
recommendations of the SIA, which emphasise the need for precise and
minimal land acquisition, timely and transparent compensation for
affected landowners, and integration of inclusive design and employment-
generation strategies, especially for youth and women. If implemented with
ecological sensitivity and sustained community participation, the City
Centre at Agatti has the potential to become a model of sustainable island
urbanism-enhancing connectivity, economic vibrancy, and quality of life
for Lakshadweep's island communities.
2. Public Purpose
The proposed development of the Agatti City Centre serves an essential
public purpose by addressing the pressing need for a well-planned,
inclusive public space that supports social, economic, and cultural
development on Agatti Island. Currently, the island lacks a structured civic
hub where residents and visitors can engage in recreational, community,
and livelihood activities. As the primary entry point to Lakshadweep and a
growing tourism destination, Agatti requires integrated infrastructure that
reflects its ecological sensitivity while enhancing local quality of life.
The City Centre aims to fulfil this objective by creating a multifunctional
space that includes food kiosks, souvenir shops, children's play areas,
performance venues, and wellness facilities designed to generate local
employment, promote cultural expression, and support eco-tourism. To
achieve this without causing undue disruption, the project proposes the
acquisition of approximately 1931 square metres of land with government
owned land, identified as the minimum area necessary to accommodate
planned facilities and ensure safe, accessible circulation. The proposed site
includes both government and private plots, selected to minimise impact
on community spaces and existing services.
This approach ensures that the project delivers long-term public benefits
while maintaining respect for land use priorities, ecological considerations,
and the cultural landscape of Agatti Island.

5. Socio-economic condition of affected families
Demographic and Educational Profile:
The affected families belong entirely to the Scheduled Tribe (ST) category
and follow Islam as their religion. A total of 10 families, comprising 59
individuals, were surveyed for this assessment. Of these, 31 were males and
26 were females, reflecting a slightly male-dominated household
composition.
The population demonstrates a high literacy rate of 96%. Educational
attainment includes 12 individuals with primary education, 34 with
secondary education, 8 graduates, and 3 individuals holding technical
degrees. All children between the ages of 6 and 14 are reported to be
enrolled in school, indicating good access to basic education on the island.
However, opportunities for higher education remain limited, often requiring
students to migrate to the mainland, particularly to Kerala, for advanced
studies.
In terms of age distribution, the affected population includes 9 children
under 18 years, 38 adults aged 18 to 55 years, and 12 elderly individuals over
55 years. Among the total population, 39 individuals are reported to be
married.
Livelihoods, Occupation and Income Sources:
The affected households in the proposed land acquisition area exhibit a
mixed livelihood pattern, combining informal employment, service-sector
jobs, and traditional subsistence activities. A total of 13 individuals are
engaged in service-related occupations, including education, healthcare,
tourism, government services, and private business. Others depend on
small-scale coconut harvesting and fishing, contributing modestly to
household income.
Prepared by APARC PVT. LTD.
Page 5
Development of City Centre
Among the affected population, 17 individuals are engaged as
homemakers, and 14 are currently unemployed, indicating a reliance on
single-income families. The community also includes 7 students and 2
teachers, reflecting active participation in the education sector.
None of the families fall below the poverty line (BPL), and most households
have access to alternative agricultural land, ensuring some continuity in
their livelihoods. Basic amenities are present, including pucca houses with
toilet facilities, cooking fuel through LPG and/or firewood, and access to
drinking water from private wells or the desalination plant supply. This semi-
subsistence lifestyle reflects a low-income but relatively stable rural
economy, rooted in traditional practices and gradually integrating formal
employment opportunities.
Poverty, Vulnerability, and Access to Welfare Schemes:
All the affected families fall under the Above Poverty Line (APL), while food
security is generally stable, and no household reported skipping meals due
to poverty. However, some families rely on subsidised food grains and other
government welfare schemes, such as ICDS, PDS, and mid-day meals.
Although most families are financially stable, the affected households
expressed concerns regarding employment opportunities and income
stability, which could be improved.
Assets, Housing, and Infrastructure Access:
All affected families live in pucca and tiled houses, with no displacement
required due to the project. Basic amenities, including electricity, primary
healthcare (PHC and private doctor), and Anganwadi services, are
available and accessible. However, the water supply is limited, with piped
desalinated water supplied only a few times a week. Households rely on
private wells for non-drinking uses. Sewage infrastructure is inadequate, with
soak pits or open drains commonly used. Transport and market access are
fair within the island, supported by a pucca road network.
Social Structure, Community Dynamics, and Aspirations:
The island operates under a patriarchal yet socially cohesive system,
characterised by strong kinship ties and high community participation.
Religious institutions, such as mosques, play a pivotal role in shaping cultural
life and influencing decision-making. There is minimal crime, and a peaceful
atmosphere prevails. Women enjoy a fair degree of mobility and freedom,
though economic participation remains limited. The community is
aspirational, particularly among the youth, who seek education and skill
development to improve their employment prospects. The local economy's
over-reliance on traditional sectors, such as fishing and government
services, is seen as a constraint. Residents expressed hope that infrastructure
improvements will lead to diversified livelihood options, especially in
medical and paramedical activities, due to this project.

6. Social Impacts
Impact on Land and Livelihoods:
The proposed project involves the acquisition of 1,931 square meters of
private land, directly affecting 10 families. Of these, 8 families participated
in the consultation process, while 2 families, whose assets include 3
residential houses and 2 restaurants, did not respond, and therefore
detailed socio-economic information on them could not be obtained.
The acquisition will also result in the loss of approximately 77 coconut trees
and 1 small tea stall. Given that coconut is a primary agricultural product
of Lakshadweep, the removal of these trees has both economic and
cultural implications. Although cultivation on the affected plots is relatively
small in scale, the impact remains significant and requires adequate
compensation under the provisions of the RFCTLARR Act, 2013.
Apart from coconut cultivation, no large-scale agricultural or commercial
activity was observed on the acquired land. The tea stall contributes
marginally to household income, whereas the two restaurants constitute
primary livelihood sources for the affected families. These impacts, along
with the loss of residential houses, are significant at the household level and
necessitate fair, transparent, and timely compensation, along with
targeted livelihood restoration measures.
Overall, while most affected families do not rely on the acquired land for
their primary sustenance, the loss of houses, restaurants, and coconut trees
underscores the need for careful mitigation to avoid hardship and ensure
equitable rehabilitation.
Impact on Infrastructure and Public Utilities:
The project involves the demolition and reorganisation of certain outdated
government buildings within the central administrative zone of Agatti Island.
However, this does not cause any adverse impact on essential
infrastructure. Critical services such as roads, electricity, water supply,
drainage, and communications will remain fully functional during all project
phases. The area proposed for acquisition excludes vital utility installations,
and any temporary adjustments will be carefully coordinated to avoid
disruption. In the long term, the redevelopment is expected to improve
infrastructure efficiency by integrating public services into a modern and
accessible civic space.
Impact on Vulnerable Groups and Social Equity
The project does not involve the displacement of residents or adversely
affect any vulnerable households, including women-headed families,
elderly persons, or persons with disabilities. All affected families belong to
the Scheduled Tribe (ST) category and follow Islam, yet none fall below the
Prepared by APARC PVT. LTD.
Page 17
Development of City Centre
poverty line or show signs of severe socio-economic vulnerability. The land
identified for acquisition consists primarily of government-owned plots and
underutilised institutional spaces, along with a limited portion of private
land. There is no evidence of landlessness, nor are any of the households
critically dependent on common property resources within the proposed
site. Rather than posing risks, the project is expected to promote social
inclusion by improving access to well-designed public spaces and
livelihood opportunities. Emphasis has been placed on universal
accessibility, gender-sensitive infrastructure, and equitable use of civic
space, with specific design features that support participation by youth,
women, and local artisans. Overall, the project is anticipated to advance
social equity and community integration.
Impact on Cultural and Social Fabric:
The City Centre development has been carefully aligned to respect the
cultural and social integrity of Agatti Island. No cultural or religious structures
such as mosques, shrines, or community-specific sites are affected by the
project. The design ensures minimal interference with community customs,
traditional land use, and social norms, thereby preserving the island's
cohesive and harmonious social fabric. Furthermore, the creation of
inclusive public spaces and amenities is expected to enhance social
engagement, support women's mobility and participation in public life, and
contribute positively to cultural expression and social equity.
Environmental and Health Considerations in the Social Context:
While the project may cause minor, short-term disruptions during
construction such as dust generation, noise, and restricted pedestrian
movement near the site these impacts are expected to be temporary and
manageable. Mitigation strategies such as restricted work hours, dust
suppression measures, noise control, and adequate public signage will be
implemented to minimise inconvenience to the community.
In the long term, the development of the Agatti City Centre is anticipated
to yield substantial benefits for the health and well-being of the local
population. The inclusion of open public spaces, shaded seating areas,
improved walkability, clean sanitation facilities, and safe drinking water
points will enhance the quality of the public realm. By promoting active
lifestyles, social interaction, and hygienic surroundings, the City Centre will
contribute to a healthier urban environment. Furthermore, thoughtful
landscape design, integration of green features, and universal accessibility
are expected to improve the island's overall climate resilience and support
inclusive community development.
Prepared by APARC PVT. LTD.
Page 18
Social Impact Assessment
7. Impact on Physical Resources
Land, Soil, and Vegetation:
The land designated for the development of the Agatti City Centre is
located on the western side of Agatti Island. It comprises sandy coastal
terrain with approximately 77 coconut trees, along with minor patches of
coastal vegetation and open plots. The soil in the area is characterized by
high salinity and low fertility, limiting the potential for systematic farming or
irrigation-based agriculture.
While seasonal cropping, paddy, or vegetable cultivation is absent,
coconut remains the principal form of cultivation in the notified plots,
consistent with the wider agricultural profile of the Lakshadweep islands. The
proposed acquisition will therefore involve the removal of coconut trees
and small areas of coastal vegetation, which represent both livelihood and
ecological value.
These impacts are localized and will be mitigated through compensatory
measures, including the valuation of lost coconut trees and provision for
replacement plantation on nearby public or community lands. Importantly,
the site does not encompass any forest land, grazing areas, or legally
protected zones, ensuring that the broader ecological balance of the
island remains intact.
Impact on Common Property Resources and Natural Systems:
The Agatti City Centre project does not affect any common property
resources such as public wells, grazing lands, religious sites, or other
culturally significant community assets. The existing surrounding open areas
and public access zones will remain available to the community, with no
restrictions anticipated during or after construction. Although the project
site is located inland and away from sensitive marine ecosystems such as
lagoons, coral reefs, or coastal wetlands precautionary measures will be
adopted during construction to prevent adverse environmental impacts.

Preface
The Union Territory of Lakshadweep, comprising a chain of ecologically
sensitive and geographically isolated islands, faces unique
developmental challenges, particularly in the area of healthcare.
Among these, Agatti Island holds strategic importance as the gateway
to Lakshadweep, being home to the only airport in the archipelago and
serving as a critical hub for transport, administration, and tourism.
Recognising the urgent need for modern healthcare infrastructure to
serve both the local population and referred patients from neighbouring
islands, the Administration of Lakshadweep has proposed the
Construction of an LPG Godown at Agatti.
This Social Impact Assessment (SIA) Report has been prepared in
accordance with the Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in
Land Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act, 2013 (RFCTLARR
Act) and the corresponding regulations for Lakshadweep. The objective
of the SIA is to assess the likely social impacts arising from the acquisition
of 2,880 square meters of land for the LPG Godown, identify concerns
and expectations of affected stakeholders, and propose effective
mitigation strategies to ensure equitable, inclusive, and sustainable
development.
The report is based on a comprehensive review of land records,
stakeholder consultations, field surveys, and institutional inputs from the
District Administration, the Department of Food, Civil Supplies &
Consumer Affairs, and the Public Works Department. It aims to provide
actionable recommendations that align with safety standards, logistical
efficiency, community welfare, and environmental sustainability.
This document serves as a foundation for informed decision-making and
the transparent implementation of the LPG Godown project, with the
aspiration that its development will set a model for resilient infrastructure,
energy accessibility, and participatory planning in India's island
territories.

1. Background of the Project and its details
The Union Territory of Lakshadweep comprises 36 small coral islands in the
Arabian Sea with a total land area of just 32.62 sq. km, of which only 10
islands are inhabited. As per the 2011 Census, the total population is 64,473.
The islands are ecologically sensitive and geographically isolated, relying
on air and sea connectivity primarily via Cochin. The administration seeks to
balance infrastructure development with ecological conservation to
enhance residents' quality of life and support sustainable tourism across the
territory.
The land acquisition for the construction of the LPG Godown is an important
landmark initiative of the Lakshadweep Administration to improve the
infrastructure standards of Agatti Island in Lakshadweep. The project aims
to provide basic and essential living standards to the local communities on
the island. The project can cater to two different and major requirements
for the local community.
The two major requirements that the LPG Godown project aims to fulfil for
the local community of Agatti Island are: first, to ensure a safe and reliable
supply of LPG by establishing a centralized storage and distribution system,
reducing dependency on irregular mainland shipments; and second, to
improve basic living standards by providing clean cooking fuel, enhancing
public health, and strengthening the island's preparedness during
emergencies. The Lakshadweep Administration wants to extend the same
facility and its service to other islands also. In such a way, the LPG Godown
at Agatti will be one of the major milestones that the Administration ensures
for the local communities.
This project supports the public purpose by ensuring energy security through
the safe and reliable supply of LPG, improving public health by promoting
the use of clean cooking fuel, creating local employment opportunities,
and strengthening the island's infrastructure to enhance the overall quality
of life for Agatti Island residents. The SIA concludes that the project is socially
desirable and necessary, with appropriate mitigation measures planned for
minor impacts like the loss of coconut trees.
2. Public Purpose
The project is classified as serving a public purpose under the RFCTLARR Act,
2013, as it addresses essential infrastructure needs, energy security, and
public health. It supports safe fuel storage and distribution for Agatti's
population, reducing reliance on inconsistent mainland shipments.

6. Social Impacts
Impact on Land and Livelihoods:
The project involves the acquisition of 2,880 square meters of private land,
impacting only two families in terms of land ownership but not resulting in
any physical displacement. The land being acquired is not used for a
primary livelihood base, as no agricultural activities or commercial
enterprises exist on the proposed plots. There are 76 coconut trees in both
plots, along with two other trees and a dug well. The loss is limited and

the land for their primary sustenance, the risk of impoverishment or
disruption in livelihood is minimal and compensable.
Impact on Infrastructure and Public Utilities:
The LPG Godown will positively impact infrastructure and public utilities by
enhancing the island's energy infrastructure, providing a centralised and
regulated facility for LPG storage and distribution, and ensuring
uninterrupted fuel availability for households, businesses, and public
institutions. It will also reduce reliance on makeshift or unsafe storage
practices, thereby improving public safety and operational efficiency
without disrupting existing utilities like roads, water supply, health centres, or
schools.
Environmental and Health Considerations in the Social Context:
In the social context, the LPG Godown project presents minimal
environmental impact as the land is non-agricultural with sparse
vegetation, and no ecologically sensitive areas are disturbed. Health
considerations are largely positive, while temporary construction-phase
effects like dust and noise may occur, they are manageable through
mitigation measures. In the long term, the project will improve public health
by promoting the use of clean cooking fuel, reducing indoor air pollution,

7. Impact on Physical Resources
In terms of impact on physical resources, the project involves the acquisition
of sandy, non-agricultural land with scattered coconut trees, resulting in
minimal disruption to soil or vegetation. No common property resources,
such as water bodies, grazing lands, or religious sites, are affected. The land
is suitable for development, and the construction of the LPG Godown will
not compromise the island's natural systems or lead to resource depletion,
making the impact on physical resources limited and manageable
8. Impact on Private Assets, Public Services and Utilities
In terms of impact on private assets, public services, and utilities, the project
does not involve the displacement of any residential structures, nor does it
affect public infrastructure such as schools, health centres, roads, or water
pipelines. The only private assets impacted are 76 coconut trees, two other
trees, and one well, which are compensable. Overall, essential public
services and utilities will remain unaffected, and the project is expected to
enhance infrastructure without causing any disruption to existing facilities.
9. Health Impacts
In terms of health impacts, the project poses minor, temporary risks during
the construction phase, such as dust, noise, and restricted access, which
can be effectively managed through mitigation measures like dust
suppression, noise control, and work-hour limitations. In the long term, the
LPG Godown will have positive health outcomes by enabling access to
clean cooking fuel, thereby reducing indoor air pollution, improving
respiratory health, and enhancing hygiene through better waste
management and drainage infrastructure.
10. Impact on cultures, social cohesion, and gender
In terms of impact on cultures, social cohesion, and gender, the project
respects the island's cultural fabric as it does not disturb any religious or
heritage sites. It is expected to enhance social cohesion by providing safe,
accessible infrastructure that supports community interaction and
collective use. The project also promotes gender inclusion by creating
employment opportunities for women and enabling greater participation
of women and youth in public and economic spaces, particularly through
the prioritisation of Self-Help Groups (SHGs) during implementation and
operation.

11. Mitigation Measures
This land of 2880 sq.m was earlier taken on lease by the UT administration,
and the existing landowners have some dispute regarding the lease
amount. However, they have no objection if the Government acquire this
land for the LPG Godown centre project by following proper law. Therefore,
all affected landowners will be compensated as per the RFCTLARR Act,
2013, including separate compensation for 76 coconut trees, two other
trees, one dug well and minor assets. However, no residential displacement
is expected, but a grievance redressal mechanism will be established to
handle compensation-related concerns. Environmentally, the project will
restore lost green cover through replantation drives using native species,
including coconut trees, ideally in a 5:1 ratio, and integrate eco-sensitive
landscaping in the final design.
The second component addresses cultural sensitivity and construction-
phase disturbances. Since at the site some structure is already existing,
construction activities will be very less, but it will be regulated to minimise
dust, noise, and disruptions, with work limited to daytime hours and
pedestrian pathways maintained for residents. Solid waste management
systems, stormwater drainage, and eco-friendly public toilets will be
installed as part of the project's commitment to sustainable infrastructure
and public health. Solar lighting and safety signage will ensure accessibility
and cleanliness of public spaces.
The third component addresses the plan emphasises inclusive economic
development and social safeguards. Project Affected Families (PAFs),
particularly women, youth, and members of SHGs, will receive priority for
employment in construction, maintenance, and recreational hall-linked
services.
12. Assessment of Social Costs& Benefits
In the assessment of social costs and benefits, the project presents minimal
social costs, limited to the acquisition of 2,880 sq. m of land from two
families, the removal of 76 coconut trees, two other trees, and one well, as
well as temporary construction-related inconveniences such as dust, noise,
and restricted access. These impacts are localised, compensable, and
manageable through planned mitigation measures. In contrast, the project
offers substantial long-term social benefits, including improved energy
security, enhanced public safety, local employment generation, reduced
dependence on irregular fuel supply, and better health outcomes. Overall,
the benefits far outweigh the costs, making the project socially equitable
and economically justified.

13. Public Hearing
As part of the Social Impact Assessment (SIA) process for the proposed
Construction of LPG Godown at Agatti Island, a Public Hearing was
conducted on 3rd October 2025 at 3:00 PM at the District Collector's Hall,
Agatti Island. The hearing was organized by the Social Impact Assessment
& Consent Society, Union Territory of Lakshadweep, in compliance with the
provisions of the Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land
Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act, 2013 (RFCTLARR Act,
2013). Wide publicity was given through local newspapers, public notices,
and announcements to ensure maximum participation. Officials from the
Department of Land Revenue, Department of Food and Supplies, Public
Works Department (PWD), Forest Department, and Agatti Panchayat
Office, along with members of the SIA Team, attended the meeting.
During the hearing, participants raised several concerns and objections
related to the proposed land acquisition. Landowners emphasized that the
land had been leased to the Government for 35 years and expressed
unwillingness to transfer ownership through acquisition, requesting
continuation under the lease model. Issues related to inadequate
compensation, declining land values, and protection of Scheduled Tribe
land rights were also raised. Some participants suggested adopting a
pipeline-based LPG distribution system instead of a storage godown, citing
space constraints and safety considerations. Officials from the concerned
departments responded to the queries and provided clarifications
regarding compensation, safety measures, and project requirements.
While clarifications were provided by the officials and SIA Team, several
participants reiterated their preference for the lease arrangement and
requested fair valuation in line with the Lakshadweep Land Acquisition Act,
1970 and the RFCTLARR Act, 2013. The proceedings were conducted
transparently, ensuring that all stakeholders had the opportunity to express
their views. The meeting concluded with a vote of thanks by Mr. Asish Manoj
P., Member of the SIA Team, and the entire session was documented
through HD video recording and photographs. The written representations
submitted during the hearing have been compiled and attached as
Annexure-8, and the list of participants is enclosed as Annexure-7.

## मंत्रालय ने नागरिकों, संस्थाओं और सामुदायिक नेताओं से बाल विवाह मुक्त भारत के निर्माण के लिए इस अभियान में शामिल होने के लिए आह्वान किया

**प्रकाशन तिथि:** 03 DEC 2025 9:30AM | PIB Delhi
**रिलीज़ आईडी:** 2198014

---

कल (4दिसंबर, 2025)नई दिल्ली के विज्ञान भवनमेंबाल विवाह मुक्त भारतके लिए100-दिवसीय गहन जागरूकता अभियान काविधिवत शुभारंभ किया जाएगा। बाल विवाह मुक्त भारत अभियानके एक वर्ष पूरे होने के उपलक्ष्य मेंइसका आयोजन किया जाएगा। महिला एवं बाल विकास मंत्रालय ने27नवंबर, 2024को बाल विवाह मुक्त भारत अभियान शुरू किया था और27नवंबर, 2025को इसका एक वर्ष पूरा हो जाएगा। कल होने वाले इस समारोह में केंद्रीय महिला एवं बाल विकास मंत्री श्रीमती अन्नपूर्णा देवी और राज्य मंत्री श्रीमती सावित्री ठाकुर उपस्थित रहेंगी।

कार्यक्रम मेंबाल विवाह उन्मूलन के लिए राष्ट्रीय संकल्प लिया जाएगा। इस अवसर परदेश भर सेप्रेरक परिवर्तन की कहानियों और अग्रिम पंक्ति के योद्धाओं के अनुभवपर आधारित विशेष रूप से निर्मित फिल्मका प्रदर्शन भी होगा। इनके जरिए सामूहिक प्रगति का जश्न मनाया जाएगा और मिशन के अगले चरण के लिए नए संकल्प के साथ जुटने का संकल्प लिया जाएगा। इस कार्यक्रम का सीधा प्रसारणhttps://webcast.gov.in/mwcdपर उपलब्ध होगा।

100-दिवसीय अभियान (27नवंबर2025 – 8मार्च2026)

तीन-चरण की योजना के साथ यह अभियान चलाया जाएगा जिसका उद्देश्य समुदायों को सक्रिय करना और सतत कार्रवाई को प्रोत्साहित करना है:

स्कूलों,कॉलेजों और विश्वविद्यालयों में जागरूकता गतिविधियांजिनके अंतर्गत वाद-विवाद,निबंध प्रतियोगिताएं,संवादात्मक सत्र और संकल्प समारोह शामिल हैं।

बाल अधिकारों,सुरक्षा और सशक्तिकरण पर संदेशों को बढ़ाने के लिए धार्मिक नेताओं,कम्युनिटी इन्फ्लुएंसर और विवाह सेवा प्रदाताओं के साथ कार्य।

ग्राम पंचायतों और नगरपालिका वार्डों को अपने अधिकार क्षेत्र कोबाल-विवाह-मुक्तघोषित करने वाले प्रस्ताव पारित करने के लिए संगठित करना।

यह राष्ट्रीय अभियान स्वास्थ्य एवं परिवार कल्याण,पंचायती राज,ग्रामीण विकासऔरशिक्षामंत्रालयों के साथ निकट तालमेल बनाकर क्रियान्वित किया जाएगाजिससे निर्बाध सहयोग और व्यापक रूप से जमीनी स्तर तक इसकी पहुंच सुनिश्चित हो सके। इस100-दिवसीय अभियान के माध्यम से,मंत्रालय देश भर के नागरिकों,संस्थाओं और सामुदायिक नेताओं से इस आंदोलन में शामिल होने और बाल विवाह मुक्त भारत के निर्माण के प्रति प्रतिबद्धता व्यक्त करने का आह्वान करता है।
